Rather than only talk about links having unique names, can you make a small section stating what sets of elements should have unique names?

Should add note about it being subject to change.

content.raw:
Drake’s SDF parsing notation:

[https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/63e8bf5d046841d5f8aad0f6b079f2c43f1fe712/multibody/parsing/detail\_sdf\_parser.cc#L335-L348](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/63e8bf5d046841d5f8aad0f6b079f2c43f1fe712/multibody/parsing/detail_sdf_parser.cc#L335-L348)

Going to try to parse and map this to our discussion.  

EDIT: This is my takeaway from our current code \(mapping from code \+ SDF frames to Mobilizer docs frames\):

```
X_PJ  --> X_PF
X_CJ  --> X_CM
```

So the `J` frame in question really seems to be `F` \(fixed\), and the child specification really supplies `M` \(mobilized\).

So potential candidates for assignments of \(Fixed, Mobilized\) frames:

\(1\) Implies joint frame is attached to child; fixed-to-parent is special:

* \(a\) `(J0, J)`
* \(b\) `(K, J)`
* \(c\) `(Jf, J)`

\(2\) Implies joint frame is attached to parent; mobilized-with-child is special:

* \(a\) `(J, Jm)`
* \(b\) `(J, K)`

My vote is for \(2\) overall, and \(2.a\) specifically.

@azeey and @scpeters - can I ask what y’all’s votes are, or if you have other suggestions?
content.html:
Drake’s SDF parsing notation:

https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/blob/63e8bf5d046841d5f8aad0f6b079f2c43f1fe712/multibody/parsing/detail_sdf_parser.cc#L335-L348

Going to try to parse and map this to our discussion.

EDIT: This is my takeaway from our current code (mapping from code + SDF frames to Mobilizer docs frames):

X_PJ  --> X_PF
X_CJ  --> X_CM

So the J frame in question really seems to be F (fixed), and the child specification really supplies M (mobilized).

So potential candidates for assignments of (Fixed, Mobilized) frames:

(1) Implies joint frame is attached to child; fixed-to-parent is special:

  • (a) (J0, J)
  • (b) (K, J)
  • (c) (Jf, J)

(2) Implies joint frame is attached to parent; mobilized-with-child is special:

  • (a) (J, Jm)
  • (b) (J, K)

My vote is for (2) overall, and (2.a) specifically.

@azeey and @scpeters - can I ask what y’all’s votes are, or if you have other suggestions?

content.raw: Add’ly, whatever we specify, I should make a PR to Drake to use this notation in the parsing code.
content.html: Add’ly, whatever we specify, I should make a PR to Drake to use this notation in the parsing code.

content.raw:
I think we've never defined before whether the joint frame was fixed to the parent or child, so we should do that. I think it's good to establish consistent notation, but given that this pull request is about version 1.4 and existing behavior, I'm not comfortable choosing between (1) and (2) here. We could say that in 1.4 the joint frame corresponds to the location of both the `F` and `M` frames in the initial configuration, and that it's undefined which one it corresponds to.

I'd be more comfortable having this discussion in the proposal pull request #7. Does that make sense? Sorry for the run-around.

My initial take is 1a or 2a.
content.html:
I think we've never defined before whether the joint frame was fixed to the parent or child, so we should do that. I think it's good to establish consistent notation, but given that this pull request is about version 1.4 and existing behavior, I'm not comfortable choosing between (1) and (2) here. We could say that in 1.4 the joint frame corresponds to the location of both the F and M frames in the initial configuration, and that it's undefined which one it corresponds to.

I'd be more comfortable having this discussion in the proposal pull request #7. Does that make sense? Sorry for the run-around.

My initial take is 1a or 2a.

content.raw:
Hmm... I think that this distinction should really happen here, given that it corresponds to mobilizations with joints, and especially if stuff like `` `<axis/>`` is defined w.r.t. the `joint` frame - and in this context, I think \(2\) would yield maximum consistency with existing behavior.

EDIT: Also, this tutorial should really only be catered to one version, so I don’t think prior versions should matter?

EDIT 2: Ignore above statement \(as long as prior versions don’t have any differences\).
content.html:
Hmm... I think that this distinction should really happen here, given that it corresponds to mobilizations with joints, and especially if stuff like `<axis/> is defined w.r.t. the joint frame - and in this context, I think (2) would yield maximum consistency with existing behavior.

EDIT: Also, this tutorial should really only be catered to one version, so I don’t think prior versions should matter?

EDIT 2: Ignore above statement (as long as prior versions don’t have any differences).

content.raw:
But isn't the `<axis>` the part that's typically identical between the fixed and mobilized joint frames?

I think (2) corresponds best to existing URDF behavior, while (1) corresponds more closely to SDF 1.4 behavior than (2) but it isn't really defined.

Any thoughts @azeey ?
content.html:
But isn't the <axis> the part that's typically identical between the fixed and mobilized joint frames?

I think (2) corresponds best to existing URDF behavior, while (1) corresponds more closely to SDF 1.4 behavior than (2) but it isn't really defined.

Any thoughts @azeey ?

Yes, <axis/> is usually in the nullspace of the mobilization. However, I don’t think that (ambiguity) is a valid reason for not assigning a frame?

content.raw:
The 1.4 spec explicitly states that the joint `<pose>` tag is the "offset from child link origin in child link frame." Later versions of the spec simply say that the pose is defined to whatever frame is specified in the `frame` attribute of `<pose>`. The SDF 1.4 implies that the joint is forever fixed to the child link, but it doesn't say so explicitly. I also don't think the run-time relationship between frames was in the scope of the SDF 1.4 spec. But going forward, I'd vote for keeping the implied meaning to avoid further confusion. As for the notations, I vote for either 1a or 1b.

Edit: I hadn't finished typing :(
content.html:
The 1.4 spec explicitly states that the joint <pose> tag is the "offset from child link origin in child link frame." Later versions of the spec simply say that the pose is defined to whatever frame is specified in the frame attribute of <pose>. The SDF 1.4 implies that the joint is forever fixed to the child link, but it doesn't say so explicitly. I also don't think the run-time relationship between frames was in the scope of the SDF 1.4 spec. But going forward, I'd vote for keeping the implied meaning to avoid further confusion. As for the notations, I vote for either 1a or 1b.

Edit: I hadn't finished typing :(

content.raw:
Aye, makes sense! My preference is more towards 1b, something that doesn't have a numeric suffix \(so that we can still name joints differently and have it be consistent with the tutorials that name joints `J0`, `J1`, etc.\).

That being said, 1c is also an option, like `Jp` / `Jf` - the joint frame fixed to the parent.
content.html:
Aye, makes sense! My preference is more towards 1b, something that doesn't have a numeric suffix (so that we can still name joints differently and have it be consistent with the tutorials that name joints J0, J1, etc.).

That being said, 1c is also an option, like Jp / Jf - the joint frame fixed to the parent.

content.raw:
Would prefer to replace the entire paragraph with:

‌

Some joint types allow degrees of freedom along a specified axis; the following frames are denoted:

* `Jf` is the frame attached to the parent link
* `Jm` is the mobilized frame attached to the child link
* `J` is the joint frame. The spec is ambiguous about this frame after motion; however, at the initial configuration \(`q0`\), the frames `J`, `Jf`, and `Jm` are all coincident.

‌

Then we can eliminate the equation \(as it's a bit ambiguous to denote the frame as a pure function of `q` without relative transforms\).
content.html:
Would prefer to replace the entire paragraph with:

‌

Some joint types allow degrees of freedom along a specified axis; the following frames are denoted:

  • Jf is the frame attached to the parent link
  • Jm is the mobilized frame attached to the child link
  • J is the joint frame. The spec is ambiguous about this frame after motion; however, at the initial configuration (q0), the frames J, Jf, and Jm are all coincident.

‌

Then we can eliminate the equation (as it's a bit ambiguous to denote the frame as a pure function of q without relative transforms).
